title: Debanking Is Real. This Is How It Happens.

rawLines.text: My lived example shows that we have
strayed too far. We shouldn't be
regularly tolerating as a society that
law-abiding citizens can have their bank
accounts frozen indefinitely by banks
without explanation. I mean, that sounds
profoundly unamerican and cannot be
squared with the original constitutional
rationale for why the Bank Secrecy Act
was okay.
[Music]
Welcome to Web 3 with A16Z. I'm Robert
Hackett. Imagine waking up one day to
find your bank account frozen. No
warning, no explanation, no recourse.
This is not a thought experiment. It's a
real situation. And it's happened not
just to crypto companies and their
founders, but to ordinary people who are
just trying to live their lives. That
includes our guest today who learned
firsthand what it means to be debanked.
In this episode, we talk about the
unseen algorithms that monitor people's
accounts, the ramifications of the Bank
Secrecy Act, and how crypto and
decentralized finance may offer a
muchneeded check and safety net against
the opaque systems of traditional
finance. Joining us are Uniswap Labs
chief legal officer Katherine Minik who
shares her personal story of being
debanked and what it taught her and A6Z
crypto finance and operations partner M.
Westerhold who helps founders navigate
these issues and who's tracked dozens of
instances of debanking across our own
portfolio. A big thank you to Catherine
for trusting us to share her story which
you can read a firstirhand account of in
an op-ed she contributed to
a6zcrypto.com
earlier this year. Find that and more in
the show notes. As a reminder, none of
the content should be taken as tax,
business, legal, or investment advice.
Please see az.com/disclosures
for more important information,
including a link to a list of our
investments.
When debanking entered the public
consciousness, there was a lot of
skepticism around this actually
happening, that this was a thing. A lot
of people hadn't heard about it. They
were confused. The people didn't
necessarily believe that it actually was
occurring. What would you say to people
who had that skepticism? I mean, I know
what I would say, which is that it
happened to me and I'm a complete rule
follower. And so, if it happened to me,
it can happen to anyone. So, that that
would be where I would start. And I
think then from there, it's easy to
start unpacking, well, wait a second,
how can it randomly happen to a person?
How can it randomly happen to a
business? What has to be at play behind
the scenes in order for those decisions
to be made? because ultimately it is a
decision by the financial institution to
debank or to close the accounts or
freeze the accounts of a customer. Some
people had reservations about sharing
their stories publicly because they
feared retribution or, you know,
endangering their families or other
sorts of things. So, I'd like to ask
you, Katherine, what got you comfortable
sharing your personal story? And I'd
like to get into that personal story,
too. I guess I got comfortable with it
because it helped explain why I think
crypto technology and in particular
DeFi, decentralized finance technology
is so important and is solving certain
problems, certain things that are broken
in the traditional finance system. And
speaking about anything personally is is
often the way to build a bridge to
someone understanding or having more of
an open mind to something that they're
uncertain about. So it became a a really
useful way to connect with someone about
something that they could understand on
a basic level. Even if the technology
industry is a little more foreign to
them, there's something very real about
the fear there almost before fear
there's embarrassment like why would why
would your bank of many years choose to
close your accounts? It it feels like a
black mark on you. And so that's why I
jokingly call myself a rule follower
when I tell this story. And I mean that,
but also I guess that's almost a
self-protective signaling of I know I
didn't do anything wrong. But even when
my husband and I went to another bank to
try to open a bank account, it felt
embarrassing to say we're here because
our bank of 10 years down the street
said we can't be there anymore. So
there's there's that whole piece of the
story. Yeah. like your own personal
feelings about it to to get through. But
at the end of the day, the story is
about something that is broken in our
banking system. And there may be good

same banking relationship with their
bank going forward. Right? There may

countless stories where there is no good

regulatory compliance theater in service
of no good end and it does real harm to

share the story because I know I'm not
alone but I also have the privilege of
being able to have other bank accounts
to feel secure in my financial life and
so I don't you know I don't have to live
with the fear that others who have
experienced this might have more deeply.
I think it's so powerful to take this
this theoretical idea like debanking,
you know, okay, there's this theoretical
thing that's happening out there in the
world, but then to put an actual face on
it and to raise your hand and say, you

to connect with people and and get

understanding of the problem. And I
guess to go to the other part of your
your question is share a little bit more

more than 10 years. And we had a

a a really important part of the story
because it's not that I could go pick up

a stable of algorithms that they use.

algorithm say this cluster says
something might be happening that

close your account or freeze your

can do that. And there's nothing you can

And the other part of the story that I

that was the other frustrating thing is
I am certain with every fiber of my
being that there was no reason to debank

to not be able to get an explanation so
that you could easily clarify what has
to be a mistake on the bank's end when

Generally, when
they would pick up the phone and

heard, "We're not banking crypto
